Speaker: addison's voice
Dialogue: The Sarah Siddons Award for Distinguished Achievement is perhaps unknown to you. It has been spared the sensational and commercial publicity that attends such questionable "honors" as the Pulitzer Prize and those awards presented annually by the film society...

Speaker: addison's voice
Dialogue: The distinguished looking gentleman is an extremely old actor. Being an actor - he will go on speaking for some time. It is not important what you hear what he says.

Speaker: addison's voice
Dialogue: However it is important that you know where you are, and why you are here. This is the dining room of the Sarah Siddons Society. The occasion is its annual banquet and presentation of the highest honor our Theater knows - the Sarah Siddons Award for Distinguished Achievement.

Speaker: addison's voice
Dialogue: These hollowed walls, indeed many of these faces, have looked upon Modjeska, Ada Rehan and Minnie Fiske; Mansfield's voice filled the room, Booth breathed this air. It is unlikely that the windows have been opened since his death.

Speaker: addison's voice
Dialogue: The minor awards, as you can see, have already been presented. Eve... but more of Eve, later. All about Eve, in fact.

Speaker: addison's voice
Dialogue: To those of you who do not read, attend the Theater, listen to uncensored radio programs or know anything of the world in which we live - it is perhaps necessary to introduce myself. My name is Addison deWitt. My native habitat is the Theater - in it I toil not, neither do I spin. I am a critic and commentator. I am essential to the Theater - as ants are to a picnic, as the ball weevil to a cotton field...

Speaker: addison's voice
Dialogue: This is Karen Richards. She is the wife of a playwright, therefore of the Theater by marriage. Nothing in her background or breeding should have brought her any closer the stage than row E, center...

Speaker: addison's voice
Dialogue: ... however, during her senior year in Radcliffe, Lloyd Richards lectured on drama. The following year Karen became Mrs. Lloyd Richards. Lloyd is the author of 'Footsteps on the Ceiling' - the play which has won for Eve Harrington the Sarah Siddons Award...

Speaker: addison's voice
Dialogue: There are two types of theatrical producers. One has a great many wealthy friends who will risk a tax deductible loss. This type is interested in Art.

Speaker: addison's voice
Dialogue: The other is one to whom each production mean potential ruin or fortune. This type is out to make a buck. Meet Max Fabian. He is the producer of the play which has won Eve Harrington the Sarah Siddons Award...

Speaker: addison's voice
Dialogue: Margo Channing is the Star of the Theater. She made her first stage appearance, at the age of four, in 'Midsummer Night's Dream'. She played a fairy and entered - quite unexpectedly - stark naked. She has been a Star ever since.

Speaker: addison's voice
Dialogue: Margo is a great Star. A true Star. She never was or will be anything less or anything less...  ... the part for which Eve Harrington is receiving the Sarah Siddons Award was intended originally for Margo Channing...

Speaker: addison's voice
Dialogue: Having covered in tedious detail not only the history of the Sarah Siddons Society, but also the history of acting since Thespis first stepped out of the chorus line - our distinguished chairman has finally arrived at our reason for being here...

Speaker: aged actor
Dialogue: I have been proud and privileged to have spent my life in the Theater - "a poor player ... that struts and frets his hour upon the stage" - and I have been honored to be, for forty years, Chief Promoter of the Sarah Siddons Society...  ... and never before has this Award gone to anyone younger than its recipient tonight. How fitting that it should pass from my hands to hers...

Speaker: aged actor
Dialogue: Such young hands. Such a young lady. Young in years, but whose heart is as old as the Theater...

Speaker: aged actor
Dialogue: Some of us a privileged to know her. We have seen beyond the beauty and artistry-

Speaker: aged actor
Dialogue: -that have made her name resound through the nation. We know her humility. Her devotion, her loyalty to her art.

Speaker: aged actor
Dialogue: Her love, her deep and abiding love for us-

Speaker: aged actor
Dialogue: -for what we are and what we do. The Theater. She has had one wish, one prayer, one dream. To belong to us.  Honored members, ladies and gentlemen - for distinguished achievement in the Theater - the Sarah Siddons Award to Miss Eve Harrington.

Speaker: addison's voice
Dialogue: Eve. Eve, the Golden Girl. The cover girl, the girl next door, the girl on the moon... Speaker: addison's voice
Dialogue: ... Eve. You all know all about Eve... what can there be to know that you don't know...?

Dialogue: Mrs. Richards...

Dialogue: Not at all.

Dialogue: I've seen you so often - it took every bit of courage I could raise-

Dialogue: Oh, no...

Dialogue: Eve. Eve Harrington.

Dialogue: ... now don't run away-

Dialogue: Hi.  Hello, darling-

Dialogue: Loud.

Dialogue: The show must go on.

Dialogue: No, dear. Margo must go on.  As a matter of fact, I see no reason why you shouldn't be Margo's understudy...

Dialogue: Do you think Miss Channing would approve?

Dialogue: I think she would cheer.

Dialogue: But Mr. Richards and Mr. Sampson-

Dialogue: Then - would you talk to Mr. Fabian about it?

Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: You won't forget it?

Dialogue: I won't forget.

Dialogue: I seem to be forever thanking you for something, don't I?

Dialogue: The bed looks like a dead animal act. Which one is sables?

Dialogue: But she just got here...

Dialogue: She's on her way. With half the men in the joint.  It's only a fur coat...

Dialogue: What did you expect - live sables?

Dialogue: A diamond collar, gold sleeves - you know, picture people...

Dialogue: Bill says actors out there eat just as infrequently as here-

Dialogue: They can always grab oranges off trees. This you can't do in Times Square...

Dialogue: Now there's something a girl could make sacrifices for.

Dialogue: And probably has.

Dialogue: Sable.

Dialogue: Gable. Why a feller like that don't come East to do a play...

Dialogue: This answer satisfies me a hundred percent.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: That happens to be your particular abnormality.

Speaker: miss caswell
Dialogue: Oh, waiter...

Dialogue: That isn't a waiter, my dear. That's a butler.

Dialogue: Well, I can't yell "Oh, butler," can I? Maybe somebody's name is Butler...

Speaker: miss caswell
Dialogue: I don't want to make trouble. All I want is a drink.

Dialogue: Leave me get you one...

Speaker: miss caswell
Dialogue: Oh, thank you, Mr. Fabian.

Dialogue: Well done. I see your career rising in the East like the sun...  ... you were saying?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Yes. Yes, it does.

Dialogue: So little. So little, did you say? Why, if there's nothing else - there's applause. It's like - like waves of love coming over the footlights and wrapping you up. Imagine... Dialogue: Don't get up. And please stop acting as if I were the queen mother.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I'm sorry, I didn't mean to-

Dialogue: Outside of a beehive, Margo, your behavior would hardly be considered either queenly or motherly!

Dialogue: You're in a beehive, pal, didn't you know? We're all busy little bees, full of stings, making honey day and night-  - aren't we, honey?

Dialogue: Margo, really...

Dialogue: Please don't play governess, Karen, I haven't your unyielding good taste, I wish I'd gone to Radcliffe too but father wouldn't hear of it - he needed help at the notions counter...  I'm being rude now, aren't I? OR should I say "ain't I"?

Dialogue: You're maudlin and full of self pity. You're magnificent.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: How about calling it a night?

Dialogue: It's a good thought.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: It won't play.

Dialogue: As a nonprofessional, I think it's an excellent idea. Undramatic, but practical...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Happy little housewife...

Dialogue: Cut it out.

Dialogue: This is my house, not a theater! In my house you're a guest, not a director-!

Dialogue: Then stop being a star - start treating your guests as your supporting cast!

Dialogue: Hear, hear...

Dialogue: Now let's not get into a big hassle-

Dialogue: You be the host. It's your party. Happy Birthday, welcome home, and we-who-are-about-to-die-salute-you.

Dialogue: Need any help?

Dialogue: If I thought I'd offended her, of all people-

Dialogue: You all put together?

Dialogue: My back's open.  Did the extra help get here?

Dialogue: Don't be dense. The party.

Dialogue: - guilty.

Dialogue: Please...

Dialogue: She loves me like a father. Also, she's loaded.

Dialogue: All you got to do is name it.

Dialogue: Well...

Dialogue: I don't know if this would be a wise move...

Dialogue: Promise.

Dialogue: I promise.

Dialogue: That's my Max.

Dialogue: Where is she?

Dialogue: If you'll excuse me-  I'll tell Miss Caswell...

Dialogue: Who's left out there?

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Too many. And you've got a new guest. A movie star from Hollywood.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Shucks. And my autograph book is at the cleaners.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: You disapprove of me when I'm like this, don't you?

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Not exactly. Sometimes, though, I wish I understood you better.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: When you do, let me in on it.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: I will.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: How's the new one coming?

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: The play? All right, I guess...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: "Cora." She's - still a girl of twenty?

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Twentyish. It isn't important.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Don't you think it's about time it became important?

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: How do you mean?

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Don't be evasive.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Margo, you haven't got any age.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Miss Channing is ageless. Spoken like a press agent.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: I know what I'm talking about, after all they're my plays...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Spoken like an author.  That slipped out, I hadn't quite made up my mind to admit it. Now I feel as if I'd suddenly taken all my clothes off...

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Week after week, to thousands of people, you're as young as you want...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: ... as young as they want, you mean. And I'm not interested in whether thousands of people think I'm six or six hundred-

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Just one person. Isn't that so?  You know what this is all about, don't you? It has very little to do with whether you should play "Cora" - it has everything to do with the fact that you've had another fight with Bill.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Bill's thirty-two. He looks thirty two. He looked it five years ago, he'll look it twenty years from now. I hate men.  Don't worry, Lloyd. I'll play your play. I'll wear rompers and come in rolling a hoop if you like... let's go say good night.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Imagine... to know, every night, that different hundreds of people love you... They smile, their eyes shine - you've pleased them, they want you, you belong. Anything's worth that.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Don't get up. And please stop acting as if I were the queen mother.

Speaker: margo's voice
Dialogue: What was it the wise man said - "This, too, will pass away"? Two weeks later - the day of the audition - all was well with Bill and me, the world and me-

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Why so remote, Addison? I should think you'd be at the side of your protegee, lending her moral support...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Miss Caswell, at the moment, is where I can lend no support - moral or otherwise.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: The ladies' - shall we say - lounge?

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Being violently ill to her tummy.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: It's good luck before an audition. She'll be all right once it starts.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Miss Caswell got lucky too late. The audition is over.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Over? It can't be. I've come to read with her. I promised Max.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: The audition was called for 2:30. It is now nearly four.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Well, it couldn't have been Max! Who?

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Naturally enough, your understudy.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: I consider it highly unnatural to allow a girl in an advanced state of pregnancy-

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: I refer to your new and unpregnant understudy. Eve Harrington.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Eve! My understudy...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Didn't you know?

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Of course I knew.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: It just slipped your mind.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: How... how was Miss Caswell?

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Frankly, I don't remember.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Just slipped your mind.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Completely. Nor, I am sure, could anyone else present tell you how Miss Caswell read or whether Miss Caswell read or rode a pogo stick.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Was she that bad?

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Margo, as you know, i have lived in the Theater as a Trappist monk lives in his faith. I have no other world, no other life - and once in a great while I experience that moment of Revelation for which all true believers wait and pray. You were one. Jeanne Eagels another... Paula Wessely... Hayes - there are others, three or four. Eve Harrington will be among them...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: I take it she read well.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: It wasn't reading, it was a performance. Brilliant, vivid, something made of music and fire...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: How nice.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: In time she'll be what you are.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: A mass of music and fire. That's me. An old kazoo and some sparkles. Tell me - was Bill swept away, too, or were you too full of Revelation to notice?

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Bill didn't say - but Lloyd was beside himself. He listened to his play as if someone else had written it, he said, it sounded so fresh, so new, so full of meaning...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: How nice for Lloyd. And how nice for Eve. How nice for everybody.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Eve was incredibly modest. She insisted that no credit was due her, that Lloyd felt as he did only because she read lines exactly as he had written them.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: The implication being that I have not been reading them as written.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: To the best of my recollection, neither your name nor your performance entered the conversation.

Speaker: miss caswell
Dialogue: Like I just swam the English Channel. Now what?

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: You next move, it seems to me, should be toward television.

Speaker: miss caswell
Dialogue: Tell me this. Do they have auditions for television?

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: That's all television is, my dear. Nothing but auditions.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Terribly sorry I'm late, lunch was long and I couldn't find a cab - where's Miss Caswell, shall we start? Oh, hello, Eve...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Hello, Miss Channing.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: How are you making out in Mr. Fabian's office?  I don't want you working the child too hard, Max - just because you promised. As you see, I kept my promise, too...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: What's all over?

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Wherever did you get the idea of having Eve read with Miss Caswell?

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: She's your understudy.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Eve? Eve, my understudy? But I had no idea...

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: I thought you knew... She was put on over a week ago-

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: It seems almost inconceivable that I haven't seen her backstage, but with so many people loitering around... well, well. So Eve is not working for Max after all-  - Max you sly puss.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Miss Channing, I can't tell you how glad I am that you arrived so late.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Really, Eve? Why?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Well, if you'd been here to begin with, I wouldn't have dared to read at all...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: ... and if you'd come in the middle, I'd have stopped, I couldn't have gone on-

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: What a pity, all that fire and music being turned off...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: You wouldn't understand.  How was Miss Caswell?

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Back to Copacabana. But Eve. Margo, let me tell you about Eve-

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I was dreadful, Miss Channing, believe me - I have no right to be anyone's understudy, much less yours...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: I'm sure you underestimate yourself, Eve. You always do.  You were about to tell me about Eve...

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: You'd have been proud of her.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: I'm sure.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: She was a revelation...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: To you, too?

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: I mean, among other things, that it must have been a revelation to have your twenty-four-year-old character played by twenty-four-year-old actress...

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: That's beside the point.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: It's right to the point. Also that it must have sounded so new and fresh to you - so exciting to have the lines read as you wrote them!

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: So full of meaning, fire and music!

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: You've been talking to that venomous fishwife, Addison deWitt-

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: - in this case, apparently, as trustworthy as the World Almanac!

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: You knew when you came in that the audition was over, that Eve was your understudy! Playing that childish game of cat and mouse...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Not mouse, never mouse! If anything - rat!

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: You have a genius for making barroom brawl out of a perfectly innocent misunderstanding at most!

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Perfectly innocent! Man have been hanged for less! I'm lied to, attacked behind my back, accused of reading your silly dialogue inaccurately - as if it were Holy Gospel!

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: I never said it was!

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Then you listened as if someone else had written you play - whom did you have in mind? Sherwood? Arthur Miller? Beaumont and Fletcher?

Speaker: max
Dialogue: May I say a word?

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: No!  What makes you think that either Miller or Sherwood would stand for the nonsense I take from you - you'd better stick to Beaumont and Fletcher! They've been dead for three hundred years!

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: And they're getting better performances today than they ever got! All playwrights should be dead for three hundred years!

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: That would solve none of their problems - because actresses never die! The stars never die and never change!

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: You can change this star any time you want! For a new, fresh, exciting one fully equipped with fire and music! Any time you want - starting with tonight's performance!

Speaker: max
Dialogue: This is for lawyers to talk about, this concerns a run-of-the-play contract, and this you can't rewrite or ad lib!

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Are you threatening me with legal action, Mr. Fabian?

Speaker: max
Dialogue: Are you breaking the contract?

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Answer my question!

Speaker: max
Dialogue: Who am I to threaten? I'm a dying man.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: I didn't hear you.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Not until the last drugstore has sold its last pill!

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: I shall never understand the weird process by which a body with a voice suddenly fancies itself a mind! Just when exactly does an actress decide they're her words she's saying and her thoughts she's expressing?

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Usually at the point when she's got to rewrite and rethink them to keep the audience from leaving the theater!

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: It's about time the piano realized it has not written the concerto!

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Where is Princess Fire-and-Music?

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: The kid. Junior.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: I must have frightened her away.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Poor little flower. Just dropped her petals and folded her tent...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: I mix what I like.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: I'm nothing but a body with a voice. No mind.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: What a body, what a voice.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: The ex-ship news' reporter. No body, no voice, all mind!

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: I will not calm down!

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: You're being terribly tolerant, aren't you?

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Well, you needn't. I will not be tolerated. And I will not be plotted against!

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Such nonsense, what do you all take me for - little Nell from the country? Been my understudy for over a week without my knowing, carefully hidden no doubt-

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: - shows up for an audition when everyone knew I'd be here... and gives a performance! Out of nowhere - gives a performance!

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: The playwright doesn't make the performance - and it doesn't just happen! And this one didn't - full of fire and music and whatnot, it was carefully rehearsed I have no doubt, over and over, full of those Bill Sampson touches!

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Paranoiac!

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Tell that to Dr. Freud! Along with the rest of it...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: That word again! I don't even know what it means...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: It's obvious you're not a woman.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Well, I am.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Don't be condescending.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: I admit I may have seen better days, but I am still not to be had for the price of a cocktail - like a salted peanut.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: The terms are too high. Unconditional surrender.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: It's not nonsense.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: I wish it were.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: I wouldn't want you to marry me just to prove something.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: I - I don't know, Bill. Just a feeling, I don't know...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Bill...  ... where are you going? To find Eve?

Speaker: karen's voice
Dialogue: On the day of the audition, my biggest worry was to keep a banana looking part of an eggplant... then Lloyd came home.  It was right after his brawl with Margo...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Lloyd, what happened...?

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Up to here! That's where I've got it - up to here! Of all the star ridden, presumptuous, hysterical-

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Margo, again...

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: And again and again! Two hours late for the audition, to begin with-

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: That's on time for Margo.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Then a childish, heavy-handed routine about not knowing Eve was her understudy-

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: It's just possible she didn't...

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Of course she knew! For one thing, Addison told her how superbly Eve had read the part-!  Karen, let me tell you about Eve. She's got everything - a born actress. Sensitive, understanding, young, exciting, vibrant-

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: - don't run out of adjectives, dear.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: - everything a playwright first thinks of wanting to write about... until his play becomes a vehicle for Miss Channing...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Margo hasn't done badly by it.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Margo. Margo's great. She knows it. That's the trouble. She can play Peck's Bad Boy all she wants, and who's to stop her? Who's to give her that boot in the rear she needs and deserves?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: It's going to be a cozy weekend.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: What is?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: We're driving out to the country tomorrow night. Just the four of us. Bill, Margo, you and I...

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Well. We've spent weekends before with nobody talking...  ... just be sure to lock up all blunt instruments and throwable objects...

Speaker: karen's voice
Dialogue: Newton - they say, thought of gravity by getting hit on the head by an apple. And the man who invented the steam engine, he was watching a tea-kettle... but not me. My Big Idea came to me just sitting on a couch...

Speaker: karen's voice
Dialogue: That boot in the rear to Margo. Heaven knows she had one coming. From me, from Lloyd, from Eve, Bill, Max, and so on - we'd all felt those size fives of hers often enough... but how? The answer was buzzing around me like a fly...

Speaker: karen's voice
Dialogue: I had it. But I let it go. Screaming and calling names is one thing - but this could mean...

Speaker: karen's voice
Dialogue: Why not? Why, I said to myself, not? It would all seem perfectly legitimate. And there were only two people in the world who would know. Also, the boot would land where it would do the most good for all concerned-

Speaker: karen's voice
Dialogue: And after all, it was not more than a perfectly harmless joke which Margo, herself, would be the first to enjoy...

Speaker: karen's voice
Dialogue: ... and no reason why she shouldn't be told about it - in time.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Hello... will you call Miss Eve Harrington to the phone, please? Not at all... thank you.

Speaker: karen's voice
Dialogue: It was a cold weekend - outside and in. Bill didn't come at all. Margo didn't know where he was and didn't care - she kept saying. Somehow we staggered through Sunday - and by the time we drive Margo to the station late Monday afternoon, she and Lloyd had thawed out to the extent of being civil to each other...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: What time is it?

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: When you asked a minute ago it was five-forty-two. It is now five forty-three. When you ask a minute from no, it will be-

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: I just don't want Margo to miss her train. As it is, she'll barely make the theater...

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Five-fifty-five. We'll be at the station in plenty of time...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: That little place just two hours form New York. It's on my list of things-I'll-never-understand. Like collecting shrunken Indian heads...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Of all people you should know what it means to want some peace and quiet-

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Peace and quit is for libraries.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Lloyd, be careful...

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Just a little skid, that's all. This road's like glass.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Karen and I just don't want an accident-

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: I have no intention of having an accident!

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: It's not important whether you do. We are wearing long underwear.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Now what's this...?

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: But it can't be! We can't be out of gas! I filled it myself yesterday!  Wasn't it full when you drove to Brewster this morning?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: I guess I didn't look. You know I don't pay attention to those things...

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Incredible.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: How much time have we?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Roughly ten minutes.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: How far to the station?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Three or four miles...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Any houses or farms around where we can borrow gas?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: None in sight, there aren't many along this back road...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Not many car either, not much chance of a lift...

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Well. No sense my just sitting here. I'm going to walk up about half a mile, just in case.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: You'll break your neck on that ice.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: What a way to die - trying to get an actress to the theater in time. Tell Max I want to be buried with royalties...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Don't joke about such things.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: How fortunate that I have an understudy so ready, so willing and so able to go on.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: The audience will want its money refunded, believe me.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Thank you, Lloyd. Godspeed.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: He always looks so pathetic whenever he does anything physical-

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: It seems to me that walking, for most people, is not very dangerous.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: I just never think of Lloyd as anywhere but indoors and anything but sitting down.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Be brave. He'll come back - with or without gas.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Do you want it on?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: It doesn't matter.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: I detest cheap sentiment.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Karen.  I haven't been pleasant this weekend.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: We've all seemed a little tense lately...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Come to think of it, I haven't been very pleasant for weeks. For that, I'm truly sorry. More than any two people I know, I don't want you and Lloyd to be angry with me...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: We're never deeply angry, we just get sore. The way you do. We know you too well...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: So many people - know me. I wish I did. I wish someone would tell be about me...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: You're Margo. Just - Margo.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: And what is that? Besides something spelled out in light bulbs, I mean. Besides something called temperament, which consists mostly of swooping about on a broomstick creaming at the top of my voice... infants behave the way I do, you know. They carry on and misbehave - they'd get drunk if they knew how - when they can't have what they want. When they feel unwanted and insecure - or unloved.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: What about Bill?

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: What about Bill?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: He's in love with you.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: More than anything in this world, I love Bill. And I want Bill. I want him to want me. But me. Not Margo Channing. And if I can't tell they apart - how can he?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Why should he - and why should you?

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Bill's in love with Margo Channing. He's fought with her, worked with her, loved her... but ten years from now - Margo Channing will have ceased to exist. And what's left will be... what?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Margo. Bill is all of eight years younger than you.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Those years stretch as the years go on. I've seen it happen too often.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Not to you. Not to Bill.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Isn't that what they always say?

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: I don't suppose the heater runs when the motor doesn't?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Silly, isn't it? You'd think they'd fix it so people could just sit in a car and keep warm...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: About Eve. I've acted pretty disgracefully toward her, too.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Well...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Let's not fumble for excuses, not here and now with my hair down. At best, let's say I've been oversensitive to... well, to the fact that she's so young - so feminine and helpless. To so many things I want to be for Bill... funny business, a woman's career. The things you drop on your way up the ladder, so you can move faster. You forget you'll need them again when you go back to being a woman. That's one career all females have in common - whether we like it or not - being a woman. Sooner or later we've all got to work at it, no matter what other careers we've had or wanted... and, in the last analysis, nothing is any good unless you can look up just before dinner or turns around in bed - and there he is. Without that, you're not woman. You're something with a French provincial office or a book full of clippings - but you're not a woman...  ... slow curtain. The end.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Margo.  Margo, I want you to know how sorry I am about this...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: About what?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: This. I can't tell you how sorry I am!

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Don't give it another thought, one of destiny's many pranks. After all, you didn't personally drain the gasoline out of the tank...

Speaker: addison's voice
Dialogue: Eve, of course, was superb. Many of the audience understandably preferred to return another time to see Margo. But those who remained cheered loudly, lustily and long for Eve... how thoughtful of her to call and invite me - that afternoon...

Speaker: addison's voice
Dialogue: ... and what a happy coincidence that several representatives of other newspapers happened to be present. All of us - invited that afternoon to attend an understudy's performance...

Speaker: addison's voice
Dialogue: ... about which the management knew nothing until they were forced to ring up the curtain at nine o'clock. Coincidence. Also every indication of intrigue, skulduggery and fraud...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Are you proud of me, Bill?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: You shouldn't have had any doubts.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: - after all, the other day was one scene, the woods are full of one scene sensations. But you did it. With work and patience, you'll be a fine actress. If that's what you want to be.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Is that what you want me to be?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: So am I.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Everything.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Don't run away, Bill.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: You're always after truth - on the stage. What about off?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Then face it. I have. Since that first night - here - in the dressing room.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: When you told me that whatever I became, it would be because of you-

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: - and for you.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: You think?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: You hear all kinds of things.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Find out.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: May I come in?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Certainly, Mr. deWitt...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: I expected to find this little room overcrowded, with a theater full of people at your feet...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I consider myself lucky they didn't throw things.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Of course your performance was no surprise to me. After the other day I regarded it as no more than - a promised fulfilled.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: You're more than kind. But it's still Miss Channing's performance. I'm just a carbon copy you read when you can't find the original...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: You're more than modest.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: It's not modesty. I just don't try to kid myself.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: A revolutionary approach to the Theater. However, if I may a suggestion...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Please do.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: I think the time has come for you to shed some of your humility. It is just as false not to blow your horn at all as it is to blow it too loudly...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I don't think I've done anything to sound off about.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: We all come into this world with our little egos equipped with individual horns. If we don't blow them - who will?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Even so. One isolated pretty good performance by an understudy. It'll be forgotten tomorrow.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: It needn't be.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Even if I wanted to - as you say - be less humble, blow my own horn... how would I do it? I'm less than nobody.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: I am somebody.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: You certainly are.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Leave the door open a bit, so we can talk.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: After you change, if you're not busy elsewhere, we can have supper.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I'd love to! Or should I pretend I'm busy?

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Let's have a minimum of pretending. I'll want to do a column about you-

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I'm not enough for a paragraph.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: - perhaps more than one. There's so much I want to know. I've heard your story in bits and pieces... your home in Wisconsin, your tragic marriage, your financial attachment to Margo - it started in San Francisco, didn't it?  I say - your idolatry of Margo started in San Francisco, didn't it?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: San Francisco. An oasis of civilization in the California desert. Tell me, do you share my high opinion of San Francisco?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Yes. I do.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: And that memorable night when Margo first dazzled you from the stage - which theater was it in San Francisco? Was it - the Shubert?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Yes. The Shubert.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: A fine old theater, the Shubert. Full of tradition, untouched by the earthquake - so sorry - fire... by the way, what was your husband's name?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Eddie...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Eddie what?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I'm about to go into the shower, I won't be able to hear you...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: I can wait. Where would you like to go? We'll make this a special night...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: You take charge.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: I believe I will.

Speaker: karen's voice
Dialogue: Some of the morning papers carried a little squib about Eve's performance. Not much, but full praise... I couldn't imagine how they found out about it - but Lloyd said Max's publicity man probably sent out the story...

Speaker: karen's voice
Dialogue: ... at any rate, I feel terribly guilty and ashamed of myself - and wanted nothing so much as to forget the whole thing. Margo and I were having lunch at "21" - just like girlfriends - with hats on...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Has Miss Channing come in?

Speaker: doorman
Dialogue: Not yet, Mrs. Richards...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Eve. I've heard the most wonderful things about your performance-

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Mostly relief that I managed to stagger through it at all...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: She was magnificent.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Then you've heard too.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: I was there. An eyewitness.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: You were there? At the play - last night?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: We're having lunch with a movie talent scout.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: They certainly don't waste much time.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Nothing definite yet - it's just to have lunch.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: They'll be wasting this much of their time at any rate. Eve has no intention of going to Hollywood.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: From the smartness of your dress, I take it your luncheon companion is a lady?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Margo.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Margo? Lunching in public?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: It's new Margo. But she's just as late as the old one.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: She may be later than you think...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: ... and now we must join our sunburned eager beaver.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Down here... here, listen to this- "... Miss Harrington had much to tell - and these columns shall report her faithfully - about the lamentable practice in our Theater of permitting, shall we say - mature - actresses to continue playing roles requiring a youth and vigor of which they retain but a dim memory-"

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: I just can't believe it.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: It get better! "- About the understandable reluctance on the part of our entrenched First Ladies of the Stage to encourage, shall we say - younger - actresses; about Miss Harrington's own long and unsupported struggle for opportunity-"

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: I can't believe Eve said those things!

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: ... what gets me is how all of those papers in town happened to catch that particular performance!

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Lloyd says it's a publicity release...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: The little witch must have had Indians runners out snatching critics out of bars, steam rooms and museums or wherever they hole up... well, she won't get away with it! Nor will Addison deWitt and his poison pen! If Equity or my lawyer can't or won't do anything about it, I will personally stuff that pathetic little lost lamb down Mr. deWitt's ugly throat...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: I guess at this point I'm what the French call 'de trop'...

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: - it's Addison, from start to finish, it drips with his brand of venom... taking advantage of a kid like that, twisting her words, making her say what he wanted her to say-

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Where'd you get all that information?

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Eve.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Eve?

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: She's been to see me, as a matter of fact she left just before you came in - you just missed her...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: That was a pity...

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: She wanted to explain about her interview, wanted to apologize to someone - and didn't dare face Margo...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: I wonder why.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: She started to tell me all about it - and she couldn't finish, she cried so...

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: You know, I've been going over our financial condition - if you'll pardon the expression...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: That's quite a change of subject.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: What with taxes coming up - and since I'm a playwright and not an oil well operator - well, I've been thinking...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: I'm trying hard to follow you.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: If - instead of waiting until next season to do 'Footsteps on the Ceiling', which is in pretty good shape - and if Margo can be talked into going on tour with 'Aged in Wood' - we could put 'Footsteps...' into production right away...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: I'm beginning to catch up.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: If we could cast it properly, that is...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Maybe get some younger actress for the part? Someone who'd look the part as well as play it?

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: You've got to admit it would be a novelty.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Now you're quoting Addison. Or Eve.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Eve did mention the play, you know. But just in passing - she's never ask to play a part like "Cora," she'd never have the nerve...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Eve would ask Abbott to give her Costello.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: No, I got the idea myself - while she was talking to me...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: With gestures, of course.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: For once, to write something and have it realized completely. For once, not to compromise-

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Lloyd Richards, you are not to consider giving that contemptible little worm the part of "Cora."

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Now just a minute-

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Margo Channing has not been exactly a compromise all these years, half the playwrights in the world would give their shirts for that particular compromise!

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Now just a minute!

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: It strikes me that Eve's disloyalty and ingratitude must be contagious!

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: All this fuss and hysteria because an impulsive kid got carried away by excitement and the conniving of a professional manure slinger named deWitt! She apologized, didn't she?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: On her knees, I have no doubt! Very touching, very Academy-of-Dramatic Arts!

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: That bitter cynicism of yours is something you've acquired since you left Radcliffe!

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: The cynicism you refer to, I acquired the day I discovered I was different from little boys!

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Hello!  ... hi, Margo... no, not at all, Karen and I were just chatting... hmm?... why - why, yes, I'm sure we can and I'm sure we'd love to... right... 11:45ish. See you then...

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Margo - and Bill - want us to meet them at the Cub Room tonight, after theater. For a bottle of wine.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Margo in the Cub Room. I couldn't be more surprised if she'd said Grant's Tomb.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: I'm glad Bill's back.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: They'd die without each other.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Darling, I didn't promise Eve anything. Just said I thought she'd be fine for the part, but there were some practical difficulties...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Such as?

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: You - for one. I told her you were set on Margo playing the part - and I certainly wouldn't make a change without your approval.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: That's fine. Fine and dandy. I'd enjoy nothing more. Just refer all of Miss Harrington's future requests to me...

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: The so-called art of acting is not one for which I have a particularly high regard...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Hear, hear...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: He does not exaggerate. I was good.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: It's been quite a night. I understand that your understudy - Miss Harrington - has given her notice.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Too bad.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: For some reason you can't just pick up champagne and drink it. Somebody's got to be very witty about a toast.  For instance...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Glory Hallelujah.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Well of all-

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Margo!

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: When? When are you going to do it?

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: City Hall, that's for prize fighters, and reporters - I see a cathedral, a bishop, banks of flowers...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: I'll marry you if it turns out you have no blood at all.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Three days, that's for the bourgeois - I see a midnight elopement, waking up a village person...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: What are you going to wear?

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Something simple. A fur coat over a nightgown...

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: There are very few moments in life as good as this. Let's remember it.  To each of us and all of us... never have we been more close - may we never be farther apart.

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: Mrs. Richards?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: For you.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Very discreet. A note right out in the open like that. Next time tell your lover to blow smoke rings - or tap a glass...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Lloyd, I want you to be big about this... the world is full of love tonight, no woman is safe...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: This beats all world's records for running, standing and jumping gall!

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: "Please forgive me for butting into what seems such a happy occasion - but it's most important that I speak with you. Please" - it's underlined - "meet me in the Ladies' Room. Eve."

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Pass me the empty bottle. I may find her... why, look. There's Rasputin.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Encore du champagne.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: More champagne, Miss Channing?

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: That's what I said, bub.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: I have no possible interest in anything she'd have to say.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Go on - find out...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Karen, in all the years of our friendship, I have never let you go to the Ladies' Room alone. But now I must. I am busting to know what goes on in that feverish little brain waiting there...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Well... all right.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Karen! How nice...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I was wondering whether you'd come at all..

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Don't get up.  And don't act as if I were the queen mother.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I don't expect you to be pleasant.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: I don't intend to be.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Can't we sit down? Just for a minute...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I've got a lot to say. And none of it is easy.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: There can't be very much-

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Oh, but there is-

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: - and easy or not, I won't believe a word.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Why shouldn't you?  Please sit down.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: You know, I've always considered myself a very clever girl. Smart. Good head on my shoulders, that sort of thing, never the wrong word at the wrong time... but then, I'd never met Addison deWitt.  I remember once I had a tooth pulled. They gave me some anaesthetic - I don't remember the name - and it affected me in a strange way. I heard myself saying things I wasn't even thinking... as if my mind were someplace outside of my body, and couldn't control what I did or said-

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: - and you felt just like that talking to Addison.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: In a way. You find yourself trying to say what you mean, but somehow the words change - and they become his words - and suddenly you're not saying what you mean, but what he means-

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Do you expect me to believe that you didn't say any of those things - that they were all Addison?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: No! I don't expect you to believe anything. Except that the responsibility is mine. And the disgrace.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Let's not get over-dramatic.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: You've really got a low opinion of me, haven't you? We'll I'll give you some pleasant news. I've been told off in no uncertain terms all over town. Miss Channing should be happy to hear that. To know how loyal her friends are - how much more loyal they are than she had a right to expect me to be...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Eve... don't cry.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I'm not crying.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Tell me. How did your lunch turn out - with the man from Hollywood?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Some vague promises of a test, that's all - if a particular part should come along, one of those things-

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: But the raves about your performance-

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: - an understudy's performance.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Well. I think you're painting the picture a little darker than it is, really. If nothing else - and don't underestimate him - you have a powerful friend in Addison.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: He's not my friend. You were my friends...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: He can help you.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I wish I'd never met him, I'd like him to be dead... I want my friends back.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Eve. I - I don't think you meant to cause unhappiness. But you did. More to yourself, perhaps - as it turned out - than to anyone else...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I'll never get over it.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Yes, you will. You Theater people always do. Nothing is forever in the Theater. Love or hate, success or failure - whatever it is, it's here, it flares up and burns hot - and then it's gone.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I wish I could believe that.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Give yourself time. Don't worry too much about what people think, you're very young and very talented...  ... and, believe it or not, if there's anything I can do-

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: There is something.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: I think I know...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Something most important you can do.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: You want to play "Cora." You want me to tell Lloyd I think you should play it.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: If you told him so, he'd give me the part. He said he would.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: After all you've said... don't you know the part was written for Margo?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: It could have been - fifteen years ago. It's my part now.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: You talk just as Addison said you did.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: "Cora" is my part. You've got to tell Lloyd it's for me.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: I don't think anything in the world could make me say that.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Addison wants me to play it.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Over my dead body...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: No... it would be so much easier on everyone concerned, if I were to play "Cora." And so much better theater, too...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: A part in a play. You'd do all that - just for a part in a play.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I'd do much more - for a part that good.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Hungry?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Just some coffee.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: I'm not surprised. After all that humble pie...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Nothing of the kind. Karen and I had a nice talk.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Heart to heart? Woman to woman? Including a casual reference to the part of "Cora" - and your hopes of playing it.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I discussed it very openly. I told her that I had spoken to Lloyd - and that he was interested.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: She mentioned, of course, that Margo expects to play the part?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Oddly enough - she didn't say a word about Margo. Just that she'll be happy to do what she can to see that I play the part.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Just like that, eh?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Just like that.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Do you know, Eve - sometimes I think you keep things from me.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I don't think that's funny.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: It wasn't meant to be.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I confide in you and rely on you more than anyone I've ever known! To say a thing like that now - without any reason - when I need you more than ever...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: I hope you mean what you say, Eve. I intend to hold you to it.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: We have a great deal in common, it seems to me...

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: - well? What happened?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Nothing much. She apologized.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: With tears?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: With tears.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: But not right away? First the business of fighting them off, chin up, stout fella...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Check.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Very classy stuff, lots of technique-

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: You mean - all this time - she'd done nothing but apologize? What'd you say?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Not much.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Groom-  - may I have a wedding present?

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: I want everybody to shut up about Eve. Just shut up about Eve, that's all I want. Give Karen more wine...  ... never have I been so happy. Isn't this a lovely room? The Cub Room. What a lovely, clever name. Where the elite meet. Never have I seen so much elite - and all with their eyes on me. Waiting for me to crack that little gnome over the noggin with a bottle. But not tonight. Even Eve. I forgive Eve... there they go.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: There goes Eve. Eve evil, Little Miss Evil. But the evil that men do - how does it go, groom? Something about the good they leave behind - I played it once in rep in Wilkes Barre...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: You know why I forgive Eve? Because she's left good behind - the four of us, together like this, it's Eve's fault - I forgive her...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: ... and Bill. Especially Bill. Eve did that, too.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: You know, she probably means well, after all...

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: She is a louse.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Groom.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: You know what I'm going to be?

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: A married lady.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: I'm going to have a home. Not just a house I'm afraid to stay in... and a man to go with it. I'll look up at six o'clock - and there he'll be... remember, Karen?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: I remember.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: You'll be there, won't you.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: A foursquare, upright, downright, forthright married lady... that's for me. And no more make believe! Off stage or on... remember, Lloyd.  Lloyd, will you promise not to be angry with me?

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: That depends.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: I mean really, deeply angry...

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: I don't think I could be.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Well. I don't want to play "Cora."

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: Now wait a minute, you're always so touchy about his plays, it isn't the part - it's a great part. And a fine play. But not for me anymore - not a foursquare, upright, downright, forthright married lady.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: What's your being married got to do with it?

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: It means I've finally got a life to live! I don't have to play parts I'm too old for - just because I've got nothing to do with my nights!  I know you've made plans. I'll make it up to you, believe me. I'll tour a year with this one, anything - only you do understand - don't you, Lloyd?

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: What's so funny?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Nothing...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Everything... everything's so funny...

Speaker: karen's voice
Dialogue: Lloyd never got around, somehow - to asking me whether it was all right with me for Eve to play "Cora"... Bill, oddly enough, refused to direct the play at first - with Eve in it. Lloyd and Max finally won him over... Margo never came to a rehearsal, too much to do around the house, she said. I'd never known Bill and Lloyd to fight as bitterly and as often... and always over some business for Eve, or a move or the way she read a speech... but then I'd never known Lloyd to meddle as much with Bill's directing - as far as it affected Eve, that is... somehow, Eve kept them going. Bill stuck it out - and Lloyd seemed happy - and I thought it might be best if I skipped rehearsals from then on...

Speaker: karen's voice
Dialogue: It seemed to me I had known always that it would happen - and here it was. It felt helpless, that helplessness you feel when you have no talent to offer - outside of loving your husband. How could I compete? Everything Lloyd loved about me, he had gotten used to long ago...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Hello... who?... who's calling Mr. Richards?

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: My name wouldn't mean anything. I room across the hall from Eve Harrington, and she isn't well. She's been crying all night and hysterical, and she doesn't want a doctor...

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Who is it? What's it all about?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Did Miss Harrington tell you to call Mr. Richards?

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: No, Eve didn't say to call him, but I remembered I saw Mr. Richards with her a couple of times - and I thought they being such good friends...

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Hello...hello, this is Lloyd Richards. Where is Eve? Let me talk to her-

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: She's up in her room, Mr. Richards. I really hate to bother you like this, but the way Eve's been feeling - I'm just worried sick what with her leaving for New Haven tomorrow, and everything...

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Tell her not to worry - tell her I'll be right over.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: I'll tell her, Mr. Richards.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Aren't you... broadening the duties of a playwright just a bit? Rushing off in the middle of the night like a country doctor?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: What would you do if, instead of Eve, the leading man had called up to say her was hysterical?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Lloyd, I don't want you to go!

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: I didn't think you would! It seems to me, Karen, that for some tine, now, you've been developing a deep unconcern for the feeling of human being in general-

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: I'm a human being, I've got some!

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: - and for my feelings in particular! For my play, my career - and now for a frightened, hysterical girl on the eve of her first night in the Theater!

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Have you forgotten about Eve? What she is, what she's done?

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Old wives' tales, born of envy and jealousy! And a phobia against truth!

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Then tell me this isn't true! That your concern for your play and career is one thing - and that poor frightened hysterical girl another - and that your concern for her has nothing to do with either your play or your career!

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: That first, last, and foremost - your reason for going now is that you want to be with Eve! Three in the morning or high noon - play or no play - wife or no wife!  Isn't it true, Lloyd?

Speaker: addison's voice
Dialogue: To the Theater world - New Haven, Connecticut, is a short stretch of sidewalk between the Shubert Theater and the Taft Hotel, surrounded by what looks very much like a small city. It is here that managers have what are called out of-town openings - which are openings for New Yorkers who want to go out of town...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: What a day - what a heavenly day...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: D-day.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Just like it.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: And tomorrow morning you will have won your beachhead on the shores of Immortality...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Stop rehearsing your column... Isn't it strange, Addison? I thought I'd be panic-stricken, want to run away or something. Instead, I can't wait for tonight to come. To come and go...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Are you that sure of tomorrow?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Aren't you?

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Frankly - yes.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: It'll be a night to remember. It'll bring to me everything I've ever wanted. The end of an old road - and the beginning of a new one...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: All paved with diamonds and gold?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: You know me better than that.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Paved with what, then?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Stars.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: What time?

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Almost four.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Plenty of time for a nice long nap - we rehearsed most of last night...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: You could sleep, too, couldn't you?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: The mark of a true killer.  Sleep tight, rest easy - and come out fighting...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Why'd call me a killer?

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Did I say killer? I meant champion. I get my boxing terms mixed.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: - come on in for just a minute, won't you? There's... I've got something to tell you.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Suites are for expense accounts. Aren't you being extravagant?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Max is paying for it. He and Lloyd had a terrific row but Lloyd insisted... well. Can I fix you a drink?

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Also with the reluctant compliments of Max Fabian.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Lloyd. I never have any, and he likes a couple of drinks after we finish - so he sent it up...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Some plain soda.  Lloyd must be expecting a record run in New Haven...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: That's for tonight. You're invited. We're having everyone up after the performance.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: We're?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Lloyd and I.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: I find it odd that Karen isn't here for the opening, don't you?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Addison...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: She's always been so fantastically devoted to Lloyd. I would imagine that only death or destruction could keep her-

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Addison, just a few minutes ago. When I told you this would be a night to remember - that it would bring me everything I wanted-

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: - something about an old road ending and a new one starting - paved with stars...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I didn't mean just the Theater.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: What else?

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: So that's it. Lloyd. Still just the Theater, after all...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: It's nothing of the kind! Lloyd loves me, I love him!

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: I know nothing about Lloyd and his loves - I leave those to Louisa May Alcott. But I do know you.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I'm in love with Lloyd!

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Lloyd Richards is commercially the most successful playwright in America-

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: You have no right to say such things!

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: - and artistically, the most promising! Eve dear, this is Addison.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Addison, won't it be just perfect? Lloyd and I - there's no telling how far we can go... he'll write great plays for me, I'll make them be great!  You're the only one I've told, the only one that knows except Lloyd and me...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: ... and Karen.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: She doesn't know.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: She knows enough not to be here.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: But not all of it - not that Lloyd and I are going to be married.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: I see. And when was this unholy alliance joined?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: We decided the night before last, before we came up here...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Was the setting properly romantic - the lights on dimmers, gypsy violins off stage?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: The setting wasn't romantic, but Lloyd was. He woke me up at three in the morning, banging on my door - he couldn't sleep, he told me - he's left Karen, he couldn't go on with the play or anything else until I promised to marry him... we sat and talked until it was light. He never went home...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: You sat and talked until it was light...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: We sat and talked, Addison. I want a run of the play contract.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: There never was, there'll never be another like you.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Well, say something - anything! Congratulations, skol - good work, Eve!

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: What do you take me for?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I don't know what I take you for anything...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: It is possible - even conceivable - that you've confused me with that gang of backward children you've been playing tricks on - that you have the same contempt for me that you have for them?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I'm sure you mean something by that, Addison, but I don't know what...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Look closely, Eve, it's time you did. I am Addison deWitt. I'm nobody's fool. Least of all - yours.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I never intended you to be.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Yes, you did. You still do.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I still don't know what you're getting at. Right now I want to take my nap. It's important that I-

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: - it's important right now that we talk. Killer to killer.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Champion to champion.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Not with me, you're no champion. You're stepping way up in class.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Addison, will you please say what you have to say plainly and distinctly - and then get out so I can take my nap!

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Very well, plainly and distinctly. Although I consider it unnecessary - because you know as well as I, what I am about to say.  Lloyd may leave Karen, but he will not leave Karen for you.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: What do you mean by that?

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: More plainly and more distinctly? I Have not come to New Haven to see the play, discuss your dreams, or to pull the ivy from the walls of Yale! I have come to tell you that you will not marry Lloyd - or anyone else - because I will not permit it.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: What have you got to do with it?

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Everything. Because after tonight, you will belong to me.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I can't believe my ears...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: A dull cliche.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Belong - to you? That sound medieval - something out of an old melodrama...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: So does the history of the world for the past twenty years. I don't enjoy putting it as bluntly as this, frankly I had hoped that you would, somehow, have known - have taken it for granted that you and I...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: ... taken it for granted? That you and I...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Remember as long as you live, never to laugh at me. At anything or anyone else - but never at me.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Get out!

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: You're too short for that gesture. Besides, it went out with Mrs. Fiske.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Then if you won't get out, I'll have you thrown out.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Don't pick it up! Don't even put your hand on it...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Something told you to do as I say, didn't it? That instinct is worth millions, you can't buy it, cherish it, Eve. When that alarm goes off, go to your battle stations...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Your name is not Eve Harrington. It is Gertrude Slescynski.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: What of it?

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: It is true that your parents were poor. They still are. And they would like to know how you are - and where. They haven't heard from you for three years...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: What of it?

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: A matter of opinion. Granted. It is also true that you worked in a brewery. But life in the brewery was apparently not as dull as you pictured it. As a matter of fact, it got less and less dull - until you boss's wife had your boss followed by detectives!

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: She never proved anything, not a thing!

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: But the $500 you got to get out of town brought you straight to New York - didn't it?

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: That $500 brought you straight to New York - didn't it?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: She was a liar, she was a liar!

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Answer my question! Weren't you paid to get out of town?

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Fourth. There was no Eddie - no pilot - and you've never been married! That was not only a lie, but an insult to dead heroes and to the women who loved them...  ... Fifth. San Francisco has no Shubert Theater and North Shore, you've never been to San Francisco! That was a stupid lie, easy to expose, not worthy of you...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I had to get in, to meet Margo! I had to say something, be somebody, make her like me!

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: She did like you, she helped and trusted you! You paid her back by trying to take Bill away!

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: That's not true!

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: I was there, I saw you and heard you through the dressing room door!

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: You used my name and my column to blackmail Karen into getting you the part of "Cora" - and you lied to me about it!

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: No-no-no...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: I had lunch with Karen not three hours ago. As always with women who want to find out things, she told more than she learned...  ... do you want to change your story about Lloyd beating at your door the other night?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Please... please...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: That I should want you at all suddenly strikes me as the height of improbability. But that, in itself, is probably the reason. You're an improbable person, Eve, and so am I. We have that in common. Also a contempt for humanity, an inability to love or be loved, insatiable ambition - and talent. We deserve each other. Are you listening to me?

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Then say so.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Yes, Addison.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: And you realize - you agree how completely you belong to me?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Yes, Addison.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Take your nap, now. And good luck for tonight.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I couldn't. Not possibly. I couldn't go on...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Couldn't go on? You'll give the performance of your life.

Speaker: addison's voice
Dialogue: And she gave the performance of her life. And it was a night to remember, that night...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Honored members of Sarah Siddons Society, distinguished guests, ladies and gentlemen: What is there for me to say? Everything wise and witty has long since been said - by minds more mature and talents far greater than mine. For me to thank you as equals would be presumptuous - I am an apprentice in the Theater and have much to learn from you all. I can say only that I am proud and happy and that I regard this great honor not so much as an award for what I have achieved, but as a standard to hold against what I have yet to accomplish.  And further, I regard it as bestowed upon me only in part. The larger share belongs to my friends in the Theater - and to the Theater itself, which has given me all I have. In good conscience, I must give credit where credit is due. To Max Fabian-

Speaker: eve's voice
Dialogue: - dear Max. Dear, sentimental, generous, courageous Max Fabian - who took a chance on an unknown, untried, amateur...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: And to my first friend in the Theater - whose kindness and graciousness I shall never forget... Karen - Mrs. Lloyd Richards...

Speaker: eve's voice
Dialogue: ... and it was Karen who first brought me to one whom I had always idolized - and who was to become my benefactor and champion. A great actress and a great woman - Margo Channing.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: My director - who demanded always a little more than my talent could provide-

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: - but who taught me patiently and well... Bill Sampson.

Speaker: eve's voice
Dialogue: And one, without whose great play and faith in me, this night would never have been. How can I repay Lloyd Richards?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Hoe can I repay the many others? So many, that I couldn't possibly name them all...

Speaker: eve's voice
Dialogue: ... whose help, guidance and advice have made this, the happiest night of my life, possible.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Although I am going to Hollywood next week to make a film - do not think for a moment that I am leaving you. How could I? For my heart is here in the Theater - and three thousand miles are too far to be away from one's heart. I'll be back to claim it - and soon. That is, if you want me back.

Speaker: aged actor
Dialogue: A good night to all - and to all a good night!

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: For services rendered - beyond the whatever-it-is-of-duty, darling.

Speaker: max
Dialogue: Come on! I'm the host, I gotta get home before the guests start stealing the liquor...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Congratulations, Eve.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Thank you, Karen.

Speaker: max
Dialogue: I'm giving her a very high-class party. It ain't like a rehearsal, she don't have to be late.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: As soon as the peasants stop pawing her.

Speaker: margo
Dialogue: ... nice speech, Eve. But I wouldn't worry too much about your heart. You can always put that award where your heart ought to be.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I don't suppose there's a drink left...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: You can have one at Max's.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I don't think I'm going.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Because I don't want to.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Max has gone to a great deal of trouble, it's going to be an elaborate party, and it's for you.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: No, it's not.  It's for this.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: It's the same thing, isn't it?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Exactly.  Here. Take it to the party instead of me.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: You're being childish.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I'm tired. I want to go home.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Very well. I shall drop you and go on to the party. I have no intention of missing it...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Who are you?

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Miss Harrington...

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: What are you doing here?

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: I - I guess I fell asleep.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Please don't have me arrested, please! I didn't steal anything - you can search me!

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: How did you get in here?

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: I hid outside in the hall till the maid came to turn down your bed. She must've forgot something and when she went to get it, she left the door open. I sneaked in and hid till she finished. Then I just looked around - and pretty soon I was afraid somebody'd notice the lights were on so I turned them off - and then I guess, I fell asleep.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: You were just looking around...

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: That's all.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: What for?

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: You probably won't believe me.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Probably not.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: It was for my report.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: What report? To whom?

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: About how you live, what kind of clothes you wear - what kind of perfume and books - things like that. You know the Eve Harrington clubs - that they've got in most of the girls' high schools?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I've heard of them.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Ours was one of the first. Erasmus Hall. I'm the president.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Erasmus Hall. That's in Brooklyn, isn't it?

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Lots of actresses come from Brooklyn. Barbara Stanwyck, Susan Hayward - of course, they're just movie stars.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: You're going to Hollywood - aren't you?  From the trunks you're packing, you must be going to stay a long time.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I might.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: That spilled drink is going to ruin your carper.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: The maid'll fix it in the morning.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: I'll just pick up the broken glass.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Don't bother.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: How'd you get all the way up here from Brooklyn?

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Subway.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: How long does it take?

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: With changing and everything, a little over an hour.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: It's after one now. You won't get home till all hours.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: I don't care if I never get home.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: That's the door.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: You rest. I'll get it...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Hello, there. Who are you?

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Miss Harrington's resting, Mr. deWitt. She asked me to see who it is...

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: We won't disturb her rest. It seems she left her award in the taxicab. Will you give it to her?

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: How do you know my name?

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: It's a very famous name, Mr. deWitt.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: And what is your name?

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Phoebe.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Phoebe?

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: I call myself Phoebe.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Why not? Tell me, Phoebe, do you want some day to have an award like that of your own?

Speaker: phoebe
Dialogue: More than anything else in the world.

Speaker: addison
Dialogue: Then you must Miss Harrington how to get one. Miss Harrington knows all about it...

Speaker: eve's voice
Dialogue: Who was it?

Speaker: phoebe
Dialogue: Just a taxi driver, Miss Harrington. You left the award in his cab and he brought it back...

Speaker: eve's voice
Dialogue: Oh. Put it on one of the trunks, will you? I want to pack it...

Speaker: phoebe
Dialogue: Sure, Miss Harrington...
